Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Bifurcation With Applications In Cardiac Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research is to explore the full potential and limitations of border-collision models in describing cardiac alternans. The project will develop a theoretical understanding of nonsmooth bifurcations as unfoldings of piecewise smooth problems, which will allow a more complete comprehension of the relation between a piecewise smooth bifurcation problem and the original smooth one. The theory developed in the present project will be applied to existing and new cardiac models to examine hybrid smooth/nonsmooth bifurcation to alternans. Theoretical and numerical predictions will be validated experimentally using isolated cardiac myocytes as well as whole isolated rabbit hearts to explore physiological mechanisms accounting for hybrid phenomena in cardiac dynamics.

Cardiac alternans is a marker of ventricular fibrillation, a fatal heart rhythm that is one of the leading causes of mortality in the Western world. Mathematical analyses combined with experimental studies of this research may lead to new insights on the physiological mechanism of alternans and therefore will impact the diagnosis and treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. The developed bifurcation techniques will provide new approaches to other nonsmooth problems in engineering and biology such as vibro-impacting systems, systems with friction, and switching in electrical circuits. The research program will train graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary environment giving them the ability to use nonlinear analyses to understand complexities in engineering and biological systems. The outreach activities will expose high school students to mathematical biology and nonlinear ways of thinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Cardiac alternans, a beat-to-beat alternation in action potential duration (at the cellular level) or in the ECG morphology (at the whole heart level), is a marker of cardiac arrhythmias, a fatal heart rhythm that kills hundreds of thousands of people in the US each year. The aim of the project was to understand, through mathematical models and experiments, how propagating action potentials in the heart undergo transition from normal to abnormal rhythms, thus leading to fibrillation. To address this problem, we performed numerical simulations to investigate a mutual contribution of two different ionic mechanisms (short-term memory and conduction velocity) to the spatiotemporal alternans formation in cardiac tissue. We also performed ex-vivo whole-heart optical mapping experiments to identify what type of bifurcation is associated with the transition from normal cardiac responses to alternans. We demonstrated that transition to alternans in the heart predominantly occurs through smooth bifurcation mechanism. Our new insights into understanding of the bifurcation to alternans and mechanisms of it formation will impact the diagnosis and treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, especially during development of cardiac rhythm management techniques. Results of this research have been reported in seven peer-reviewed journal publications, two conference proceedings, and numerous presentations at the international and local conferences.

Broader impacts

The NSF grant helped me to develop and support a highly interdisciplinary research and educational environment, and to attract students from different disciplines: biomedical engineering, electrical engineering, and mathematics. Over the duration of the grant, one postdoctoral researcher, six graduate and four undergraduate students were involved in the project. Two students graduated with MS degrees, and two students graduated with PhD degrees. Moreover, my laboratory was involved in various outreach activities. Specifically, I participated in President's Distinguished Faculty Mentor Program at the University of Minnesota (UMN), served as a judge in the FIRST Robotics competition and in the State Science and Engineering Fair. Members of my laboratory provided a mentorship to 6th graders who came to the campus and participated in scientific activities. We also participated in Teaching SMART (Science, Math and Research Technologies) student-run organization at the UMN and worked with underrepresented 5th through 8th graders in an afterschool program.
